content.title: Livedo Reticularis
content.definition: Livedo reticularis is a reticular (net-like) pattern of reddish-blue skin discoloration caused by decreased blood flow and deoxygenation in the cutaneous microvasculature, appearing as lace-like mottling typically on the legs and trunk.

appearance.blanching: Blanches with pressure in physiologic forms

physiologic.cutis_marmorata: Normal in infants and young women with cold exposure
physiologic.mechanism: Vasospasm of arterioles with venous pooling

cholesterol_embolization_syndrome.clinical: Livedo, blue toes, renal failure, eosinophilia

diagnosis.history: Duration, cold sensitivity, medications, associated symptoms
diagnosis.examination: Pattern (reticularis vs racemosa), ulceration, systemic findings
diagnosis.skin_biopsy: May show vasculitis, thrombosis, cholesterol clefts

explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Livedo Reticularis include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Livedo Reticularis.

learning_objectives: Distinguish livedo reticularis from livedo racemosa
Recognize livedo in cholesterol embolization syndrome
clinical_pearls: Livedo racemosa (broken pattern) is more likely pathologic than reticularis
After vascular procedures, livedo + blue toes suggests cholesterol embolization
Antiphospholipid syndrome is an important cause of pathologic livedo
Cutis marmorata in infants is physiologic and benign
